name: Fredholm
tagline: Solves integral equations with singular divergences numerically
body:
### Solving Fredholm equations numerically.

[Inhomogeneous Fredholm equations](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fredholm_integral_equation) of the first order (inhomogenious) can be written as follows:


Here functions K (called Kernel) and g (inhomogeneous term) are given and f(s) is the function to solve for.

In this form, such equation is often encountered in the quantum many-body physics. Depending on the context and details, they are referred to as either integral equations for quantum scattering problem, Dyson's equation or Bethe-Soppiter but have similar underlying feature.

For such applications, some common features arise:

1. The delta function term could be singled out.

2. If real and complex parts are separated, function diverges under the integral, principal value integral. There are resonances/bound state amplitute contributions.


### Usage.
Let's get down to bussiness, to defeat the Huns! First you need to make sure you have Python 2.7+ with the numpy packages properly installed at your system of choice. To see if that is the case try:
```
python import numpy 
```
If there is no exception, it probably works.

Now we can download the package:
```
git checkout
```

And run tests to see if everything works:
```
python test.py
```

2. Borzov et al., "Nature of 3D Bose Gases near Resonance", [Phys. Rev. A 85, 023620 (2012)](http://pra.aps.org/abstract/PRA/v85/i2/e023620)
